isis.stitle: SINGLE REDUCTION CARRIERS: ROCKWELL - REASSEMBLE - ADJUST PRELOAD OF PINION BEARINGS

svcprocinfo.para: Refer to DRIVE PINION BEARINGS - PRELOAD for the proper setting.

note.para: If a press is not available, or the press does not have a pressure gauge, use the yoke or flange method to adjust preload. The spacer or spacers control the preload adjustment of the drive pinion bearings.

step1.para: Put the drive pinion and cage assembly in a press, gear head (teeth) toward the bottom.
Install a sleeve of the correct size against the inner race of the outer bearing ( Figure 66).

Apply and hold the correct amount of pressure to the pinion bearings. Refer to DRIVE PINION BEARINGS - PRELOAD . As pressure is applied, rotate the bearing cage several times so that bearings make normal contact.
While pressure is held against the assembly, wind a cord around the bearing cage several times.
Attach a spring scale to end of cord.
Pull the cord with scale on a horizontal line. As the bearing cage rotates, read the value indicated on scale. Make a note of reading ( Figure 66).

note.para: Do not read starting torque. Read only the torque value after the cage starts to rotate. Starting torque will give a false reading.

step1.para: Measure the diameter of bearing cage where the cord was wound. Measure in inches or centimeters ( Figure 67).

figure.caption: Figure 67. Measure Diameter of Bearing Cage Where Cord Was Wound

step1.para: Divide the dimension in half to get the radius. Make a note of radius dimension.
Use the following procedure to calculate the bearing preload (torque).
Pounds pulled x Radius (inches) = in-lbs. preload x .113 = Nm preload OR
Kilograms pulled x Radius (centimeters) = kg-cm preload x .098 = Nm preload
Examples:
Reading from spring scale = 7.5 lbs. (3.4 kg)
Diameter of bearing cage = 6.62 inches (16.8 cm)
Radius of bearing cage = 3.31 inches (8.4 cm)
7.5 lb. x 3.31 in. = 24.8 in-lb. preload x .113 = 2.8 Nm preload OR
3.4 kg x 8.4 cm = 28.6 kg-cm preload x .098 = 2.8 Nm preload
If the preload (torque) of pinion bearings is not within specifications, do the following procedure then repeat Steps 4 to 8.
To increase preload, install a thinner bearing spacer. To decrease preload, install a thicker bearing spacer.
Check the bearing preload with the drive pinion and cage assembly installed in the carrier. Follow the procedures to adjust preload of pinion bearings, yoke or flange method.
Install the input yoke or flange, nut and washer * on the drive pinion. The yoke or flange MUST be against the outer bearing.

note.para: If the fit between the yoke or flange splines and drive pinion splines is tight, use a press to install the yoke or flange ( Figure 68).

figure.caption: Figure 68. Use Press to Install Yoke or Flange

step1.para: If a press is not available, use the three-piece pilot tool for installation. Refer to INSTALL TIGHT FIT YOKES.

caution.para: Do not install tight fit yokes or flanges on shafts using a hammer or mallet. A hammer or mallet will damage the yoke or flange and/or bearing.

step1.para: Temporarily install the drive pinion and cage assembly in the carrier. Do not install shims under the bearing cage ( Figure 69).

figure.caption: Figure 69. Temporarily Install Drive Pinion and Cage Assembly in Carrier

step1.para: Install the bearing cage to carrier cap- screws. Washers are not required at this time. Tighten the capscrews hand tight.
Fasten a yoke or flange bar to the input yoke or flange. The bar will hold the drive pinion in position when the nut is tightened ( Figure 70).

figure.caption: Figure 70. Fasten Yoke or Flange Bar to Input Yoke or Flange

step1.para: Tighten the nut on drive pinion to the correct torque value ( Figure 70). Refer to the TORQUE CHART.
Remove the yoke or flange bar.
Attach a torque wrench on the drive pinion nut. Rotate the drive pinion and read the value indicated on torque wrench ( Figure 71).

figure.caption: Figure 71. Rotate Drive Pinion and Read Torque Value

step1.para: If the preload (torque) of pinion bearings is not within specifications, remove the pinion and cage assembly from carrier. Do the following procedure, then repeat Steps 1 to 7.

step2.para: To increase preload, install a thinner bearing spacer.
To decrease preload, install a thicker bearing spacer.

step1.para: After adjusting preload of pinion bearings, remove the drive pinion and bearing cage from carrier. Refer to REMOVE THE DRIVE PINION AND BEARING CAGE FROM CARRIER.
If the carrier has a cover and seal assembly over the bearing cage, install a new seal into cover as follows.

step2.para: Apply Lubriplate or grease used for wheel bearings to the seal lips and cavities between lips. REFER TO GROUP 10 - LUBRICATION.
Apply a sealing compound on the outer diameter of seal.
Put the cover in a press, large diameter toward the top.
Support the cover under the small diameter opening with metal or wood blocks ( Figure 72).
Press the seal into cover until seal is flat against the bottom of bore. Use a sleeve or seal driver of the correct size that fits against the metal retainer of seal ( Figure 72).

note.para: If a press is not available, use a mallet and the sleeve or driver to install the seal ( Figure 73).

figure.caption: Figure 73. Use Mallet and Sleeve or Driver to Install Seal

warning.para: Wear safe eye protection. Do not hit steel parts or tools with a steel hammer. Parts or tools can break and cause injury.

step1.para: If the pinion seal mounts directly into the bearing cage, install a new triple-lip seal as follows:

step2.para: The old triple-lip seal can be installed into the bearing cage if the seal is not worn or damaged. Refer to DISASSEMBLE THE DRIVE PINION AND BEARING CAGE.
Apply the same lubricant used in the axle housing to the outer surface of the seal and the seal bore in the bearing cage ( Figure 74).

figure.caption: Figure 74. Apply Lubricant to Outer Surface of Seal and Seal bore

caution.para: Make sure that the seal lips are clean and free from dirt and particles that will cause a leak between the yoke and the seal.

step2.para: On reused seals, apply Lubriplate or wheel bearing grease to the seal lips.
Put the drive pinion and cage assembly in a press, seal bore toward the top.

Press the seal into bearing cage until flange of seal is flat against the top of bearing cage. Use a sleeve or seal driver of the correct size that fits against the metal flange of seal. The diameter of the sleeve or driver MUST be larger than the diameter of the flange ( Figure 75).

figure.caption: Figure 75. Press Seal into Bearing Cage

note.para: If a press is not available, use a mallet and the sleeve or driver to install the seal ( Figure 76).

figure.caption: Figure 76. Use Mallet and Sleeve or Driver to Install Seal

warning.para: Wear safe eye protection. Do not hit steel parts or tools with a steel hammer. Parts or tools can break and cause injury.

step2.para: After the triple-lip seal is installed, a gap of approximately .015 to .030 inch (.38 to .76 mm) between the flange and bearing cage is normal ( Figure 77).

figure.caption: Figure 77. Normal Size Gap Between Flange and Bearing Cage

step2.para: Check the gap with a feeler gauge at several points around the seal. The gap must be within .015 to .030 inch (.38 to .76 mm). The difference between the largest and smallest gap measurement MUST NOT exceed .010 inch.
